comments.commentBody:
What did Big Daddy Bob spend on that safari? Maybe $15,000?

If he was really motivated by the desire to help solve the elephant "problem" then, according to the Foggin article cited above, he could have translocated TEN elephants to areas outside of Zimbabwe's human/elephant conflict zone by DONATING that same amount to translocation specialists like Conservation Solutions (http://www.conservationsolutions.info.)

But that wouldn't have been as much fun as shooting off a big gun and playing the hero to those poor villagers, would it Bob?

I saw the show last night and I really thought Mr. Isherwood would offer theatre goers a little more than just a plot summary as a review. My friends and I felt this show was a very pretentious piece of theatre, and regardless of the prizes it may have almost won we felt as though it was a bit of a cartoon.
The scenery was lovely, the lighting was beautiful, but the acting was little more than caricatures of stereotypes. And Robin Williams simply played Robin Williams-just toned down Good Will Hunting style. The actor who played the translator gave the most nuanced performance by far, but even so, his character was the 'good guy', stuck between two different types of 'bad guys.' The character of Uday Hussein may as well have been Darth Vader or Voldemort he was so lacking in complexity. Rather than enlighten, the oversimplification of a very intense set of circumstances in our nation's history really does a disservice and I'm surprised Mr. Isherwood let that slide in his review.
Nothing real or interesting or intelligent about this play. It will die at the box office as word-of-mouth gets out.

Agree with others that the critic had alterior motives for his negative rating perhap carries a grudge against the choreographer. Show had everyones interest throughtout the evening along with great music that brought back memories of the old time broadway. Sets were bright, routines were fresh and creative and Radcliffe was fast on his feet, quick with his lines, and embraced the total audience as few shows do. I would  see this show over and over when in New York. Harry (Radcliffe is moving on after this show) and may be the last time to see his majic  on Broadway. Dont miss it if you have the chance.
A "seasoned hunter"? Cowardly redneck, more like it. It's not the elephants that are over-populated. It's the people. Is Parsons going to shoot them as well?

He's cashing out. September of last year:

"GoDaddy.com, the closely held website that registers Internet domain names, has put itself up for sale in an auction that could fetch more than $1 billion, people familiar with the matter said.

...Private-equity firms are expected to bid for the company, which currently has more than 43 million domains under management."

@Geoff #36 - No, you wouldn't use a USB drive for your phone or tablet, you'd use a memory card. If your Apple i-phone, i-pad, i-whatever doesn't have a microSD as is pretty much standard on almost every phone, down to the basic free phone, well, what can I say. Not that the new Amazon service will help you - i-products not supported.

For those asking for alternatives - Namecheap.com is offering a deal for people to switch their domains.

Namecheap's special offer is good until 11:59pm EST of April 1st. The coupon code for the offer is BYEBYEGD (bye bye GoDaddy)

Namecheap.com - they've been around since 2001 and are one of the top rated hosts on the web. I'm moving my domains over and definitely won't miss godaddy. (note - I'm not affiliated in any way with namecheap. use whatever host you'd like. But I hope people do more than just say they are outraged - it's actually taking the time to move their domains that really sends a message.)
These people spending ridiculous amounts are unbelievable.  It's not that difficult to find an iPad 2 using retail tracking sites like iPad2Tracker.com.
Disgusting.  Someone asked for Competitors - try Bluehost - great customer service and no sexist ads.

Those Africans need an American to fly over there to shoot elephants? Nobody in Africa has their own guns?

It shows tremendous markmanship to accurately site and hit the largest land animal on earth. Give me a break.

What's next, a Royal Bengal Tiger hunt? There's still small but diminishing number remaining.

I cannot believe that a corporate identity would be so inept and stupid to participate in such a venture and not expect a backlash. Despite comments that this wont affect or has anything to do with his Go-Daddy business is wrong.

It is his customers who have provided him with success and a means to an end to participate in such an activity. But it is also his customers - like me - who will withdraw their support and take their business elsewhere.

In age of the tightest corporate scrutiny of CEO's Parsons proves to me he's not up to the task.
Disgusting

I can't believe Mr. Parsons thinks he's doing anyone a favor. I am an IT consultant, and I'm letting you know right now all the business I do with GoDaddy is going away. I'm migrating our Exchange hosted accounts, SSL certs, countless domains, DNS services and many others. Disgusting.

Do you want to feed children? Donate money UNICEF.

comments.commentTitle: I wish it could stay but the collections survival dictates that it must move
comments.commentBody:
I saw the documentary first about six months ago. I had heard about the collection and Lincoln University's involvement several years before in an NPR story. Even though my father (and four uncles) are LU alumni, I had never heard that Lincoln University held the majority on the Board of Trustees. Dad would bring us back to campus yearly for a reunion and commencement. From the film, I thought it unfair for the state to actively intercede to break the Dr. Barnes' Indenture of Trust. I also felt that Lincoln had been strong-armed by the state of Pennsylvania. I also thought that LU was foolish for selling their majority position on the Board to Big Charity for cents on the dollar.

Then I went to Merion and saw the collection. Actually, I saw a little less than half the collection since the second floor has already been closed for conservation and shipping to Philadelphia! The canvasses are magnificent. Within the space of a few rooms I saw Renoir's progression from a portraitist to grand works that are alive with color and light to very blurred depictions where the color is pretty much all there is...figures in the foreground and background barely discernable. The placement of the art work with the wrought iron and silver pieces (hinges, locks, keys, etc.) and furniture of the collection make for a real experience. I loved my time there. However, somewhere between halfway and 3/4 the way through my tour, I realized that if the collection isn't moved to a new location, isn't exploited and sold more effectively, it will cease to exist.

The collection's current location can't drive enough eyeballs past it to carry its own freight. Breaking his wishes is a shame yet a testament to Dr. Barnes' aesthetic senses. In one-hundred years, much of the collection could be in terminal disrepair and some pieces would need to be sold in order to save the others. I wish it were different but in order for it to exist as a single collection forever, The Barnes has to move. Darnit!

I didn't relish listening to the gift shop person pontificate on how the Foundation is anxious for the move and that they all disagree with the documentary's premise...Well, yeah...once you stack the Board with folks that will vote your way you sort of get what you want, don't you?

I disagree with those who say that the art is being held hostage in Merion. The art isn't being held hostage. Your own attitude is holding you hostage. Anyone who wants to see the collection at the North Latches Lane location before it moves to Philly proper, I recommend they find time to do so. Just don't wait too long. I plan to see it once or twice more before it moves. And I will definitely see it at the new location, too. There is at least one Lautrec and a couple Modigliani that I just HAVE to see.

comments.commentTitle: Great movie then, great movie now
comments.commentBody:
I first saw this movie in college less than 20 years after its release -- it was "old" then -- and it blew me away. A true epic telling an interesting story extending over multiple generations. I love the reference made to Elizabeth Taylor's aging -- some gray hair and nary a wrinkle.

I had read that it was Rock Hudson's favorite and it is probably his best performance. It ranks with Virginia Woolf for Elizabeth for me.

Interesting that Crowther's review makes no mention of Dennis Hopper or Sal Mineo...

Fabulous on a big screen in the original aspect ratio.

The killing was to feed a village that was starving to death. The killing was not sport. PETA killed 2,200 cats and dogs last year. Animals not used for those who have no food but uthanized carelessly. If your so concerned for the welfare of the Elephants stop taking your kids to the circus, alert the local media when the circus is in town and get involved with the thousands of abused cats and dogs that need a voice in our local shelters. Stop judging and get involved with the real issues. Here is recent video of a elephant shackled and struck with a pitchfork and flinched with pain-http://alturl.com/rghou or http://alturl.com/xe54o Please get some perspective!
What a low life coward.  Parsons is pure trash taking pleasure in killing a beautiful sensitive creature.
Boycott, boycott, boycott.

As I customer of GoDaddy for several years I can tell you that GoDaddy provides the best customer service of any company I have ever dealt with, bar none.  When it comes to inspiring employees to care about customers, Bob Parson's is certainly doing something right, and I have to factor that into my overall judgment of him as a person.

comments.commentTitle: Some of the most AMAZING 12 minutes in cinema
comments.commentBody:
Okay, so I'm a bit late to the party. With all the movie options available today, I can be a bit slow at ticking the animated fare off my Netflix queue. After all, I have no small children at the house, and there's just so much to choose from.

But I am SOOOO glad I got around to watching this movie. It was a pure wonder. While Manhola is correct to say that the rest of the movie can't live up to the opening, it's not because the movie isn't terrific. It's simply because the opening twelve minutes of this film are among the best sequences of cinema I've ever seen, animated or otherwise.

The filmmakes take you through all of human emotion in those 12 minutes. From puppy love to aged emotion. From optimism to devastation. Surely, the films core audience will be too young to get the meaning of images like Carl sitting outside of the hospital room, but for the adult in the audience there will be fewer images made more powerful. Pulled apart as it's own short film, that opening itself would be worth the price of admission. A beautifully rendered love story that will make your heart swell.

As for the rest of the movie, I never stopped smiling. The talking dogs. The lanky bird. Even the portly boy scout. All of these characters come together to keep you on the edge of your seat.

A wonderful film. Well worth the price of admission.
The Pink Berets, aka the "ninja bunnies" are female.  It seems odd to me that your review sites a lack of female bunnies, when they do in fact have a considerable amount of screen time.
